I'd like to know how precisely they controlled for variables such as:  1. mass of each bullet (measured, not just average); 2. amount of gunpowder in each cartridge; 3. mass of each block of wood; 4. geometry of each block of wood; 5. mass of each nail; 6. air temperature and 7. relative humidity at the time of each gunshot.  That's seven variables, from an amateur, without thinking too long.  Surely that's enough noise inserted into the system that it could be masking the data that is being sought.  However, perform this experiment a significant number of times, and you have a better chance that any difference in data will show itself above the noise level.

How bout this: 0+0=0 and -1 + 1 = 0.
In other words the energy put into the system where the block doesn't rotate has an upward vector distributed uniformly to every particle of the block, where as the spinning one has one side with more energy in its upward vector for those particles, but the ones on the opposite side have less. In both cases, the total energy of the system is the same, but between each case, its distribution isn't.
Schematically, given a 30 N total upward force,
CenterOfMass: Left(10N), Center(10N), Right(10N) = 30N
RightOfCenterOfMass: Left(5N), Center(8N), Right(18N) = 30N - although the right side has more energy and would go higher, the left side has less and drags it down and although this produces a spinning effect, the total upward force is the same.
This is why I always thought momentum should be the deciding factor in stopping power.  Instead, everyone talks about bullet  kinetic energy.

The one hit on the sides has a higher torque, and was supposed to go a bit higher , since the distance of the point where it was hit by the bullet was at a bigger distance than the one hit at the centre. Since the distance was more from the fulcrum in the side hit, it was supposed to go higher, but that was maintained by wasting out energy in a rotational form, and eventually both rose to the same height. This is a case of an inclined plane, where the pivot is the fulcrum. Similar to a door, that requires more energy if pushed nearer to the hinge , than the one pushed at the door knob area.

Don't trust intuition. Trust conservation of [linear] momentum: mv=(m+M)u where m is the mass of the bullet, M is the mass of the block, v is the bullet speed, and u is the initial speed of the center of mass of the block+bullet. That depends only on the fact that the bullet embeds itself so that the it is a totally inelastic collision. It does not depend on where on the block it embeds itself, or whether it is spinning too. It would be nice to make a video response, but it really is that simple. What is also not intuitive is that it goes straight upward when hit off to the side, but v (the initial bullet velocity) actually points upward, so the initial and final momentum (after bullet embeds itself) must also point straight upward.

Take a few standardized 1 ft 2x4s, put them horizontally on the floor of something that has standard smoothness, like a basketball court, hit one of them horizontally with a good quality crossbow dead center in the middle, using a standardized metal short arrow, and see how far it slides straight. It should slide fairly far, with no spins.

Repeat, hitting a second 1 ft 2x4 horizontally with the same crossbow, but this time towards one of its ends. It should slide away in the same direction like the first piece, but this time will be spinning in circles.

Friction should be equal in both cases, at least for that same initial distance which both should cover.

This approach should give you enough length and distances to be able to measure variations, especially if the sliding is considerably far (10, 20, 50 feet).

Most importantly, you need the arrow to stay in the wood, though you need them to go deep enough. So, test various thicknesses until you ensure the same, as arrows going completely through the wood would defeat the whole purpose.

Probably a length of 2 feet could be better, as it increases your measurement accuracy (for rotational momentum, lever arm, etc.). One suggestion I saw below is to use rubber, which could probably be better (than wood), as crossbow arrows should surely get stuck in rubber. But rubber has high friction, which could seriously affect the accuracy of the outcome.

Are you starting with the assumption that each round of ammunition is the same?  Reloaders struggle to maintain consistent velocities due to powder weights, the speed and consistency of the primer and the depth the bullet is seated as well as how tightly the case is crimped around the bullet.   We evaluate a sample of 5 to 10 rounds of a test load for extreme spread of velocity, average as well as standard deviation.  An SD of 20 feet per second yields accuracy differences 5% greater than 15 for SD.  15 fps SD is a good average benchmark for most reloaders to start with.  To get to 10 fps SD you only gain about another 3% in accuracy over a 15 for SD so we start getting into diminishing returns.  Most if not all commercial ammunition publish some velocity data but don’t list the test conditions (temp, humidity, barrel length etc) and almost none will give an SD.  My point is that your energy delivery method may be very inconsistent.  To negate the energy input question I would suggest pneumatic fired ball bearing or slug where you can control the masses and velocities more precisely.
Use HDPE blocks instead of wood. The results would have less error of margin.

If there will be no penetration of a block at all (neglecting energy of the bullet disintegration) the angular momentum would be about 50% of energy of linear momentum, as you said. I believe both moment of inertia and leverage factor into this phenomenon. Consider, instead of a small block had you used a 2"x4"x8' plank pivoted the same way in the middle. A bullet fired in the center might have been raised the plank some measurable distance - say 4" at both ends. However, had the 2nd bullet been fired into the plank 4' off center would not have raised the whole 8 foot plank. I suspect due to the distance of the bullet striking the plank from its center of gravity, all the kinetic energy from the bullet would have been converted into angular velocity causing the plank to spin on its central axis and the plank would not have risen vertically. This is because the lever arm at point where the bullet strikes is large compared to the distance to the plank's center of gravity.

In your example, the lever arm was too small thereby the bulk of the kinetic energy translated into linear vertical thrust while the angular velocity was too small due to the short lever arm length.

This channel has improved a lot since 2013. This is literally a high school physics problem on conservation of linear momentum and angular momentum in the case of completely inelastic collisions.

Two things:
A) Conservation of Momentum (both linear and angular) is only applied when the net external forces acting on the system sums to zero. In this case, gravity exists, so there's an assumption that the impact is a very tiny moment in time. But is it? A way to avoid this would be to shoot horizontally on a frictionless surface so the net external forces would be zero. I have done this and gotten the same results (linear momentum is conserved within measurable limits).
B) Another interesting observation is when the wooden block gets struck by the bullet close to the edge, the center-of-mass shifts from the center of the block (before it is struck) to a point to the right (how far, depends on their masses). You can actually see this wobble for the bock around this new center-of-mass. Interesting stuff!

7 years after the fact, I just want to toot my own horn and say that I nailed this quiz from start to finish. Basically, I’m pretty goddamn smart.

1. Momentum as you described it is not conserved. Momentum is a vector. The bullet is flying horizontally and the wood flies upward. But of course the momentum is preserved because the contraption the wood block is attached is part of the system and the Earth that contraption is secured on is part of the system. And naturally the Earth has much more mass than the wood block. Think of a basketball when you dribble it. The momentum flips over at every bounce. How is it preserved if it is a vector. Because the ball is bouncing from the Earth. The momentum of the total system ball + earth is preserved at every bounce.

2. Using conservation of energy by just looking at the energy of the wood block is also wrong. I believe most of the energy of the bullet turns into heat at impact. You can verify it by measuring the mass and the speed of the bullet and mass and speed of the wood block.

In short, you are not looking at the total system when you try to set up and explain the conservation of momentum and conservation of energy equations. You are ignoring the momentum exchange with the earth and the heat energy generated at impact. This system cannot be explained with the simplistic and partial systems approach in this video. Momentum and energy are conserved at the total system level.

Most of the comments are also confused. They are lost in secondary and tertiary effects like the consistency of the wood, etc. I haven’t seen an explanation that focuses on the first order effects. Maybe because they are misled by the explanations in the video.

I think this problem is basically a convoluted and violent ball bouncing problem that is difficult to model. Even a tennis racket hitting a tennis ball is easier to model than this.

Perhaps you are aware of all of this but you are trying to create a puzzling situation where there is none.

How I thought of it was: hitting the block straight on meant more of the energy went into breaking wood fibers, like a crumple zone in a car during a head on collision, and hitting it to the side meant less of the energy got absorbed by the wood, like getting T-boned in a wreck - the car won't deform as much but it'll spin that remaining energy out instead.

I believe Veritasium's answers are incorrect. Here is the correct answer.  When the bullet strikes the block off-center, the block begins to spin.  As the block begins to spin, the block acts as a lever and the nail pushes downward against the plexiglass stand.  The plexiglass structure sits on solid ground, so as the nail pushes downward against it, the effective result is the nail is helping to launch the block upward (just as anything that gives the earth a downward shove will itself experience an upward acceleration).  To prove my theory, you can do the experiment again, removing the plexiglass stand at the exact moment of bullet contact (I'm not sure how this could be done).  Or more easily you could suspend the block using a squishy support structure instead of the rigid plexiglass. If you do this the result will be much different, and the spinning block will not go as high as the non-spinning block.

To determine exactly how the energy is being transferred from a bullet to a catch material, everything in the experiment needs to be controlled much more tightly. The bullet needs to be of consistent mass and accelerated to a consistent velocity every time (maybe using electromagnetics.) Both the bullet and the catching material need to be much more consistent. Different catching materials should be used, including non-deformative materials that would have an elastic collision with the bullet. The initial momentum of the bullet and the mass of the catching material can vary as long as it remains consistent with each bullet and catch-material combination. Perform the experiment in a vacuum and measure temperatures before and after. In the end, a conservation of energy must be observed.
However, going back to the original experiment of just using wood, we saw that there was great variation in results between the few repetitions that were done. This indicates that many many more repetitions need to be done before we can calculated an average height for both the non-rotating blocks and the rotating blocks separately. I suspect that after a large number of repetitions, we would see a more apparent difference in average height of the rotating blocks with respect to the non-rotating blocks. Because the bullet translates all of its momentum to the wood in the first fraction of a second, it will lodge itself into the wood to a depth that is nearly the same in both rotational cases, I suspect that the energy lost to friction and heat will also be roughly equal in both cases. The fact that so much energy is being translated into angular momentum is very likely to result in the over all average height of the rotating blocks to be less than the non-rotating blocks.
Unfortunately, I think Derek's presentation of the analysis of this riddle is misleading (that the blocks of wood reach the same height in both cases) because the performance of his own experiment was incomplete and led to invalid results. I like that Derek is making us think about what we are observing, however, I think a proper explanation is deserved.

For greater clarity of differences in the depth of penetration of bullets, it is necessary to give the bar a shape that will be characterized by:
1) a distribution of mass that is non-uniform in height, but symmetric about the axis of symmetry.
2) the mass of the central part of the bar above the center of its base must be greater than the mass of each of the edges separately.
The lower mass of the edge of the bar gives an increase in the acceleration it acquires relative to the edge of the bar of a regular shape when firing at the edge of the base, respectively, the rotation speed of the bar will be higher, which will mean that most of the kinetic energy of the bullet will go into the rotation energy of the bar than in the case of a shot to the edge an ordinary bar in the shape of a rectangular parallelepiped. The conversion of much more of the kinetic energy of a bullet into rotational energy when fired at the edge of the bar will make a big difference when comparing the depths of the holes left by bullets fired at the center of its base and at the edge.
As a special case, you can take a T-shaped bar suspended with the head upwards on nails inserted into the lower part of its legs. To show that a significant increase in the speed of rotation in the case of a shot into a t-shaped bar is not associated with a change in mass when switching from a bar of a conventional shape, but is precisely a consequence of a decrease in the amount of energy spent on deformation of the bar body, you can make a bar from a material denser than that of which the original bar was made.

That explains the rotation of block, without a difference in height from the non-rotating block

To get a readable result, you need to fire into a less dense (and more homogeneous; wood's density varies a LOT across the grain) material, so the bullet travels further and the 1% difference between the two shots is more noticeable.

you also need to control for the rifle. rifle bullets go different speeds. you probably need to first control for internal ballistics, by cooling the rounds and ensuring you fire them from the gun at the same temperature (a warm barrel heats the powder in the round, which makes your muzzle velocity higher) and also chronograph each shot to control for minor variances in muzzle velocity.

at such a small scale, the deformation of the bullet may even play a part. a bullet that deforms more may impart more energy quicker than another, which could skew results. the deformation itself could skew results since a more deformed bullet might look like it went shallower even if it had deeper proportional penetration. this could be offset by using a hardened round with a discarding sabot, but that could make material choice very difficult, as it would likely make the round go straight through a soft material.

but conservation of angular momentum applies to the entire system bullet + wood right ? Let's call it b+w. The center of mass of this system is called G. The bullet is at the position B. So the position of the bullet relative to the center of gravity is the vector GB . The bullet has a linear momentum p

You can calculate the angular momentum L = GB /\ p of the entire system b+w, even before the bullet enters the wood.

first experiment, the bullet is travelling towards the center of mass of the system b+w : angular momentum is zero from the start because GB and p are colinear
second experiment, the bullet is offset from the center of mass of b+w, so from the begining there is a non-zero angular momentum L = GB /\ p

It's a bit more complicated because the center of gravity is moving as the bullet approches but I think that's the reason : the angular momentum was there from start.

Bullets have a variation in the number of feet per second (fps) they achieve. Say you have a box of ammo rated for 1200 fps. Shoot 5 rounds from this box of ammo out of the same rifle, and you might see 1190, 1180, 1210, etc fps. This changes the foot-pounds of energy delivered to the target -- wood blocks, in this case. So, even if the wood blocks are identical in weight and size, they will receive a variable amount of energy from the bullets, resulting in a variation of height achieved. You would need to use a chronograph while shooting the blocks, and only compare heights when identical fps is achieved

Kinetic energy isn't really what it sounds like as it is still a form of potential energy - the difference between two reference points. i.e. the potential is energy is force x distance and the kinetic energy is force * time. They both require a force and a position/time to calculate and these vary. The block gained the extra energy from the TIME the bullet took to transfer it's energy, not the distance it travelled into the block.
Momentum on the other hand requires neither force, nor position as it is purely a measure of the energy contained within a body due to motion.

Another great experiment for the conservation of momentum appeared on my A level physics paper as a bonus question.

A man fires a series of guns horizontally from a height of 1m. All the same weight bullet however one exits the barrel at 360m/s another at 400m/s and the last at 430m/s. How long does it take for the bullet to hit the ground for each?

Assuming you're on a flat plane and air resistance is negligible.

Workings
t = √(2d/g)
t = √(2(1)/9.81)
t = 0.45 seconds

The trick being that each despite the difference in velocity all hit the ground in 0.45s. :)

I think there is an error in measurement and the results are being looked at in a wrong way. When bullet gets stuck in the wood the centre of mass of the entire system lowers in both the cases. And also, the system always rotates about its centre of mass, in the second case, which lies in the fourth quadrant with respect to the centre of the block. Let's test all the hypotheses and this theory by using basic physics.

So if we say that the centre of block reaches the same height at the highest point doesn't imply that centre of mass of the system reaches the same height. There is some energy loss due to inelastic collision, but let's assume it is insignificant as X -Ray shows bullet reaches the same depth. (Will come at it later)

On applying linear momentum conservation, the centre of mass would have same initial velocities and would indeed reach the same height, which would mean that at some instant or permutation, due to rotation, the centre of rotating block would even be higher than the non rotating one, but we observe that in very favourable cases it reaches at most the height of 1st block. This would imply that the centre of mass stays lower than the non rotating block, but that's impossible since that would imply that linear momentum is not conserved. So premise of different heights of centre of mass is not possible and both have same initial kinetic energies, so the observation that centre of the block reaches the same height is wrong, and it must be the difference in amount of heat dissipated to account for additional rotational energy, implying different bullet depths (That's what the video says)

So my conclusion is, all the three options to the original question are correct, since we are observing the centre of the block, which keeps rotating with respect to the centre of mass of the system, which in this case reaches the same height so the centre of the rotating block will always be within plus minus (r-h) units of the centre of first block, where r is the offset of centre of block with respect to the centre of mass of the 2nd system and h is the vertical offset. An electric analogy. We have a capacitor C charged to a voltage V. We switch on a second capacitor C in parallel. What about V' ?
1/ Total capacity C' = 2C. Initial charge Q is CV. It is evenly split between 2 capacitors = 2 CV'. Therefore V'= 0,5 V
2/ Initial energy E = CV²/2. If we believe it is conserved, E=C'V'²/2. Therefore, V'=0,707 V. How come ?

Here is my take: The bullet is low mass and very high speed. The wood block is so massive and slow that we have an impedance mismatch.

The bullet penetrate about the same depth in both case. For the bullet, it makes no difference to hit in the center or the side. The block take so much time to start rotating that it appear as immobile from the reference frame of the bullet.

The geometry is also important. If the bloc would be an elongated rectangle, we would get a much different effect between center and far side of the rectangle. The difference is related to the center of mass. In the extreme case of very long piece of wood and bullet hitting close to one side, that side would lift and the other stay put, That side would lift higher than the entire board when hit in the middle.

The other extreme case is, once again, using a long piece of wood but aligned vertically this time. Let say 1 inch by one inch at the point of contact with the support and location of the bullet and 10 foot long pointing toward the sky. The bullet can hit dead center at 0.5 and 0.5 or hit closer to a side such as 0.75 inch and 0.75 inch,. The center of mass is 5 foot away, so the difference between 0.5 to 0.75 inches, which is a delta of 1/4 inch) is such a tiny fraction of 5 foot. It is clear that most energy would be converted to vertical lift, not much to rotation.

Well I was wrong, who would've guessed.

The entire experiment hinges on one big fundamental assumption: all bullets shot impart the same exact force.

Since the additional slow-mo footage suggests a large variance, this entire test is fairly inconclusive, without at least a much larger sample size.

With a random deviation in the force of up to, say 20% (using the footage the actual relative force of each bullet tested could be calculated), comparing a sample size of 5 to 3 is completely inconclusive.

When examining a single independent variable like this (the distance relative to center of mass) I always like to look at the extremes for potential insight.

If you were able to stretch the wood without changing its mass or other material properties (ie. being too thin to contain the bullet), so that the impact location is an arbitrary distance away from the center of mass, eventually you would reach a point where so much of the bullet's energy is converted into torque, that the wood object would not even lift off the glass. There is no real arguing around this fact - Whatever happened here is only possible due to how small the offset is compared to the forces involved.

Practically, you could probably accomplish this by using one or more light metal rods of a foot or two in length, attaching a small piece of wood (large enough to fully contain the bullet upon impact) and balancing the system to weigh the same amount as the original wooden block (or simply repeat the experiment with a larger, heavier piece of wood). Air resistance should be negligible at these velocities. The elasticity of the metal should be kept in mind but with a strong enough construction (thin metal rods welded in triangle shapes like a crane) should be negligible.

here is an intuitive way to rationalise the outcome: a wooden block the size of a point has no edge or centre, so there's only one height it can reach when shot. an infinitely wide block also has no edge or centre (every point is a centre), so again there's only one height an infinitely wide block can reach. so everything in between must behave similarly. this is not a mathematical proof, but often such extreme case analyses yield elegant explanations.

I believe that most of the difference is caused by the velocity of the bullet and the way the motion of the bullet, is transferred to the motion of the wood.

We test fired different 45 caliber lead rounds from different guns with different barrel lengths and velocities at a fire rated post office safe. At lower velocity the paint on the safe was not damaged, the lead bullet fragmented into powder.

As we increased the velocity of the same round, it removed the paint, and dented the safe door. The bullet fragmented to powder.

As we increased the velocity further, we penetrated the metal and caused a molten burned edge around the hole on the metal safe with shallow penetration. The bullet either fragmented or boiled away.

When we fired the same round from a long barrel it penetrated the metal of the safe cleanly, and then bored into the magnesium oxide, totally fragmenting or boiling away.

The first round we fired that did not remove the paint from the safe door, moved the safe door the most. It caused the safe door locking rods to strike the cabinet.

In comparison the last most powerful round did not move the whole door noticeably at all. It did not depress or dent the metal on the face of the door that was struck.

Having shot perhaps 100,000 thousand rounds and projectiles in my life, I have noted phenomena of velocity, that have almost gotten myself and others hurt. Very unforeseen violent reactions have occurred when only small differences in placement of the round upon a target occurred. After seeing it the explanation is usually a simple one, however unforeseen.

I believe that is where most of the effect is being creating. The wood is absorbing much of the motion of the round upon destruction in both cases.

Because the wood is giving, and obviously the spinning wood gives way or moves more than the wood that does not spin. The wood is equalizing the effect to some extent.

Consider shooting an aluminum soda can with a high and low velocity round. The low velocity round, can put a hole into the can and a hole out of the can and throw the can off a shelf. A higher velocity round can leave the can solid upon a shelf after putting a hole into the can and another hole as it exits the can.

The variables are too great to take any exacting conclusion away from this experiment.

I have an idea for a new experiment with this projectile motion setup you have made.

First of all, using a much softer wood such as that of balsa wood will increase the penetrative power. Balsa wood also has a fairly uniform soft texture, so it should be able to be replicatable between experiments. Using metal plates on the front and back of the block will give it extra mass to cause the moment of inertia to be increased. This will increase the rotational energy, while decreasing the lift height so as to allow the rotating block to spin away from the bullet faster, causing it to lodge in the block sooner, and thereby penetrate less than the block shot in the center. This would seem to me to be the best chance of finding out if it is the penetrative depth that correlates with the spin rather that some other force acting upon the block. This could also be tested more by shooting blocks in different places and finding a linear equation that predicts the rotations per second by measuring the mass of the bullet, the initial velocity as it exits the barrel of the gun, the distance of the impact from the center of the block, and the mass of the block. it would need three shots minimum on identically set up blocks of same mass, bullets that are measure to be exactly the same weight and have the same amount of propellant, and then replicated three or more times with different mass blocks to measure as a variable in the equation to account for the inertia in heavier blocks.

In this setup, I predict that the heavier the block, the faster the block will spin due to the moment of inertia on the side that was not hit as there is a larger mass to lift than the lighter blocks. Granted, there should be equal inertial force on blocks of different masses, but I have an inkling of a feeling that the rotations per second may be reliant on whether the block is able to transfer the energy through the Mould effect, thereby increasing the rpm by using a 'whipping' action by driving one side up while the other side stays motionless.

Please let me know what you think of this, I would be interested in hearing your thoughts on this.

The distance the bullet penetrated into the block is not really the relevant distance here... it is the distance the bullet traveled while slowing down to reach the speed of the point of contact with the spinning block, compared to slowing down to meet the speed of the center of mass. Since the block is rotating, the bullet actually travels a greater distance in this case. Trying to approach this like a Physics 101 problem, here's what I got. It turns out to be mighty close to the explanation here, but whittled down a lot by lacking all the train-of-thought explanations and experimental effects and further investigations shown in the vid.

There are 3 main conserved quantities to consider: energy (E), momentum (p), angular momentum (L). Each of these is considered at the moment of impact.

L is not a factor in predicting the height. It tells only how the spins differ for the two cases.

p says that at impact, both bullets have the same p, as do both blocks. And it is mute on the matter of spin, before/after. Therefore, the bullet-block velocities are the same in both cases, resulting in the same height attained.

E says that the KE's of both incoming bullets are the same, so both bullet-block KE's should be the same, post-impact. But the spinning block has put some of its KE into rotation, leaving less for translation, so its upward velocity should be less at impact.

So the p and E conservation laws conflict on the result! How can this be???

ANS: Hint: "Inelastic collision."

We haven't accounted for all the energy in our E analysis. Both collisions are Inelastic; possibly with different coefficients of elasticity; thus allowing the p analysis to be correct (which it must be, because there IS no way out of that argument).
When the off-center bullet strikes its block, the block has some additional "recoil" due to rotation, that wasn't present in the centrally-struck block. So the same amount of KE goes into translation, while an additional amount of KE goes into rotating the off-center block.

So the final answer is, both blocks attain the same height.

I would take it to an absolute. Make a longer board just long enough that it does not lift off the nail when struck on the end of the board by the bullet. Then see if the bullet can lift the same length board off the nail when struck in the center.

What is happening is that the center of the board becomes a fulcrum when struck. So the weight of the block during the positive rotational acceleration is divided at the center of its mass. And most of the bullets force can be converted to upward motion. It is the positive rotational acceleration that is lifting the board, by moving the bullets force to the fulcrum point. The far side of the board not hit by the bullet actually moves downward, as the fulcrum point applies downward pressure to it.

Wood is not an engineering material. Although we have practical data about its actual performance, its use in aircraft is sketchy at best. You can see by the different results you had from different pieces of wood that it is not a good material to test with.

The way the boards are balanced may also play an important part in how they move when struck. Consider a board that the nail is not centered by measurement, but is centered by weight. Once spinning this could cause a big difference.

I think if you suspended the board at each end and shot that board off to one side, that you could get even more dramatic results. Because the bullet could transfer more of its energy to moving the wood. But this is going to be sketchy no matter what using wood.

Sincerely,

William McCormick

My first thought was rather than figure out how to measure the difference in the distance the bullets travel, I'd try to make sure the penetration depth is the same. I suspect zero penetration would be the easiest to achieve. So I'd shoot at a steel block. That way the energy transfer should show up as a difference in the reaction of the blocks. The problem here is that there could be some difference in the amount of energy spent splattering the projectile all over the place. That might be hard to measure.

To measure differences given the current set up (wood blocks), how about measuring the volume of the hole the bullets create. The bullets might not travel straight in the wood, they could tumble. Whether tumbling or not, some energy in the bullet will be spent creating the hole in the wood. So the bullet shot at the center of the block should create a larger hole than the bullet shot to one side. I would measure what I put into the hole - so start with say 100 cc of liquid and find out how much liquid is left when the hole is filled.

If you used water, the wood will absorb some part of the water, so some liquid that won't be absorbed would be good. The geek in me would suggest mercury, but that's pretty nasty to handle. An oil might not absorb as quickly as water. But you also need something with low viscosity to get into all of the irregular nooks and crannies that will be in the hole.

You'd want to use something other that wood that would not absorb water. A soft acrylic or other plastic, or perhaps a very dense foam might work. I'd probably experiment with a few different materials to find one that would work well for the experiment.

I think you got it wrong. This experiment clearly demonstrates the law of levers. When the bullet hits the centre, it would have to balance both the clockwise as well as the anticlockwise moment of force of the block i.e. the entire weight of the block. On the other hand, when the bullets hits the side, it needs to produce only anticlockwise moment of force, and since,
M.A. =effort arm / load arm
It would need half the energy to bring the block to the same height. The other half of the energy would be converted to rotational kinetic energy.
Note - The energy lost as sound and heat is equal in both the cases.

As the bullet hits the block it begins an energy transfer through the entire block -think of it as vibration or waves of force-. Though some dissipate as heat, and sound, there is also a heat and movement transfer -molecule level- through the entire block.

When it strikes it in the middle, the waves of energy/force travel evenly through the block dissipating evenly through the whole block, reaching the edges of the block at similar intervals and generating vibrational echos through the entire block.

When it strikes it on the edge, the waves of force reach the edge of the block faster on the side of the impact, but take longer to reach the other side.

However, the block serves as a force transfer medium, thus its molecules move within the block (think of a box full of minute marbles) as the waves of force travel through the block, and the molecules bounce off of each other within the block as it receives any impact.

Since the impact side´s molecules all collide with each other faster and before the molecules on the other side of the block, at the time of the impact, the molecules of the impact side have/receive and transfer more momentum than the molecules on the oposite side.

So the bouncing vibrations of the molecules on one side is faster and more powerful than the other side generating more force on one side than the other, but no generating EXTRA energy. 

More energy is "compacted" in one corner, faster and more powerful than the other corner, and it generates more and faster "echoes" on the impact´s side.

So the rotation of the block is not explained as a phenomena of creating energy, but rather as a phenomena of energy distribution in wave form at molecular level, where one side receives and produces more and faster waves of impact than the other side.

I know this video was over a year ago, but I watched it then and wasn't satisfied and I've rewatched it now and I think I know a better way of explaining it. The block shot in the middle IS rotating, but it is rotating away from itself in two equal parts, either side of the bullet. Imagine shooting it in the centre with a much larger calibre gun, the block would split in half and each half would spin off, one clockwise the other anticlockwise. This rotational energy is easily seen when a low calibre gun shoots the block to the side, because there is less wood on one side of the bullet and the energy can be more easily imparted into the smaller object. However if you shoot a low caliber gun into the middle of the block of wood this energy rotating in opposite directions is invisible to the human eye, because each half of the block tries to spin opposite the other but not enough to actually tear the wood apart.

Therefore, both blocks are technically rotating, but only one shows it in a way we would traditionally call 'rotation'.

In the case of the block which was shot off center, the reason why it rotates is because gravity pulls down on the side that did not receive the thrust, so there is no "extra energy" coming from the bullet. to visualize it, think about dropping those blocks from the same height. Put two pins under each block so that the blocks are resting on the pins. Now, Remove both pins under the first block simultaneously. The block falls with no rotation. In the second case remove only one pin. The block spins while falling. The blocks have the same mass and fall from the same height, so the kinetic energy at the point of contact with the ground is the same. The second block rotates so it must have more energy than the first one. on the other hand the potential energy of both blocks is the same. The explanation must not be how far the bullet penetrates.

The physics weren't thoroughly explained. The linear momentum part is correct. The angular momentum part skipped an important detail: At the time of firing the bullet, the bullet DOES have angular moment relative to the axis of rotation of the block, defined as the bullet mass (M) times the distance to the axis (R) times the velocity of the bullet (V), so L=M*R*V (or I*omega, where I=MR^2 and omega=V/R). After the collision, this angular momentum is conserved in the combined bullet-block system. The spinning of the block at the peak of its launch is not indicative of extra rotational energy in the system.

In result, the bullet shot to the center gives both sides of the block same amount of momentum and kinetic energy but the bullet shot to the right-side of the block gives it's energy mostly to that part of the block. Actualy, the difference in total final energy is due to the fact that the second system (with the offset bullet) was different from the start.

If you consider the system as the brick+the bullet even as they are separated you can clearly visualize that the initial angular momentum of the first system is 0 (as the bullet is going exactly in the direction of the center of mass of the system). But the second system (the one with the bullet offset to the side) has a part of it moving in a direction not going through the center of mass, therefore it has angular momentum which is, certainly (disconsidering the decay of energy from collision with air particles and stuff), the same as the final.

I have something to say here, and hope that the veritasium guy reads and responds to it..
Aren't we ignoring the fact that the case where bullet hit is offset from the center of mass(say, towards the right), the platform on which the block's axle was resting also applies a torque (actually an impulsive torque at the suspension point of contact of the block) on the bullet-block system, the very moment the block is hit? The force is vertically upwards since the axle-supporting surface is flat and horizontal, and the point of application of force is offset from the vertical line passing through the center of mass of the bullet-block system. Well, of course the axle applied an equal and opposite reaction on the supporting surface the exact same time, but we don't have to worry about that; when analyzing a system, we have to look at force applied ON the system, not by the system.
There are two things going on here, which I believe, like other things in this video, are enlightening..
1. This force applied by the supporting surface on the bullet-block system alleviates any momentum conservation that does not count the supporting surface (and the surface stands and the earth and so on...) as a part of the system for which the conservation has to be applied. Not even the linear momentum conservation that we easily applied to compare/calculate height to which the blocks rose. This force is what takes the block higher above than our own intuition would allow it to rise.
2. The force is also the reason for a torque on the bullet-block system. However, as our intuition would have it, the torque is oriented so that it would rotate the bullet-block system clockwise. But the bullet-block system actually rotate counterclockwise, as seen in the video! That means, if it were not for the supporting surface, the bullet-block system would rotate much more rapidly, since then there would be no clockwise torques to slow or down! (Go ahead, try the experiment without any supporting surfaces.).

What kind of bullet(the projectile type matters) did you use? Basically ammunition design has an entire field of engineering based around penetration. For cheap ammo (paper punchers) they go with the cheapest manufacturing. For defense purposes, they want to minimize penetration and conservation of energy in order to 1: maximize transfer of kinetic energy to target (more damage and higher chance of incapacitation.) 2: Minimize the chance of punch through and injury to a bystander. 3: Minimize the energy of ricochets on miss and risk to bystanders.

While I find this very intriguing, there are far too many variables in this experiment.
Wood is a poor choice, as its density is unequally distributed. Therefore, penetration depth will not be consistent, nor will the center of gravity. (Ten blocks of wood of identical weight, and dimensions, will all have slightly different centers of gravity).

A bullet from a gun, offers several variables: 
Muzzle velocities are not consistent, even with the highest quality rounds.
There is also the matter of projectile weight and shape, as those can vary from bullet to bullet.
There is also the matter of the placement of the rifle. If it is not 100% secure, than the rifle may move during/between shots, altering the total energy, and trajectory, of the bullet.


I would recommend using something like a small air cannon, with a ball bearing as a projectile. Projectile weight, dimensions, trajectory,  and velocity, should be as close to identical as possible.

As for the target, I'm not sure what would be the most consistent, but I'm thinking Lexan blocks. Dimensions, weight, density distribution, center of gravity, and placement, should be as close to identical as possible.


The goal is to remove as many variables as possible, leaving a much clearer result.

I think the rotating is caused from the unequal disbursement of momentum and the shift in weight, which is due to where the bullet impacted on the block. Before they were shot they all weighed the same, but once they were shot the balance in weight shifted on the object that was shot off to its side.  Think of a balance scale, if the weight was placed center mass of the scale there would be no shift, but if you added more weight to one side it will begin to tilt in that direction.  The block that was shot center mass did not rotate, because it was able to evenly disburse the momentum between both sides of where the round impacted.  On the block that rotated, one side endured more of the momentum than the other, and that is why it rotated.  It took longer for the momentum to reach the other end of the block, and by the time it did it was already to late.  Those are my theories anyways

To maintain the essential parameter, an inelastic collision, while increasing the difference in lost energy, there are five parameters that can be changed. The mass of the projectile can be increased, the initial velocity of the projectile can be decreased, the mass of the target can be decreased, the moment of inertia of the target can be increased, and the arm of the projectile from the center of mass of the target. To do such, I would suggest replacing the wooden block with a long corrugated plastic piece with some extra mass on the ends. I would also replace the gun with a bow with a heavy arrow (small diameter; covered with sandpaper to help it stay in the plastic if needed) but low velocity (partial draw maybe). Hopefully that would help, but I would also do some experiments on the conditions to figure out the  ideal circumstances since I am getting bogged down in the equations.

When the block was centered this muzzle blast energy was imparted equally across the bottom of the block.

When shooting the block off center more muzzle blast energy was delivered to the right of center and less to the left.  This in ADDITION to the energy delivered to the block by the bullet.


If you were to move the muzzle back  at least a foot you can prove me right or wrong.

Firstly, I think we can change the experiment from vertical to horizontal, so that the weight of the block doesn't act on the incoming bullet anymore.
Secondly, we can reduce the mass of the block, for example using a smaller block or a block made of Styrofoam. Next we have an assumption that the blocks of wood had a true trajectory. I am pretty sure that in the "off center" shot the focal point of the spin was NOT the resting (nail) center before the rifle shot. In other words the nail center had a spiraling path on the way up (a wobble). That means the center of gravity had shifted once the lead became part of the spinning block of wood. That actually contributes to the conservation of energy by extending the initial moment at the time the bullet hit the wood. As the bullet- laden half of the wood started it's downward trajectory gravity also had an added effect of pulling down on the heavy side (wanting to increase the speed of rotation), then alternately expelling that energy as the heavier side had to be lifted on the upward half of the rotation.

So you see, the added energy for the spin came from the effects of gravity on one side of the off center block, and gravity also played a major role in the conservation of total energies as the block continued to spin it's wobbly way into the air.

Gravity folks.

OK here goes my explanation. It is based on a general assumption that seems to have been made. The best way to explain it though is in parts.

First, it is true that extra energy existed in the wood block's flight which was shot off center, but the proposed reasons operate under a false assumption, which is why the truth has been so illusive.

"So what are we missing Matt?"

Well a couple of things. The extra energy came before the bullet hit the wood in the off center shot, as the piece of wood was lifted up off the ground (or what ever it was resting on before hand).

As the bullet hit the wood on the "centered" shot most of the kinetic energy went straight towards lifting the test block. NOW, in the "off center" shot a moment was created focusing energy that lifted the block, and the potential energy stored by the opposing half of the off center block was transformed into kinetic energy by the force of gravity. Had the other side of the block opposite of where the bullet hit been kept from moving in the downward direction then the test may have had a different outcome. So the impact point (approximately one half the distance from the center to the edge) coincides with the amount of energy potential for gravity and the requisite energy needed to create the spin.

Next, .....
BIGGER BULLETS!!!!!

I think there is an assumption that is being made that is not true. The best way to try and explain it would be to take each aspect one at a time.

First we have assumed that it took extra energy to make the block spin. In a way that was true, but it wasn't the energy of the bullet that added this energy. As the block was lifted off the ground to it's resting place it had gathered potential energy. So as the bullet side was lifted the potential energy on the opposing side of the block, having no restriction transformed it's potential energy into kinetic energy as gravity pulled it down. There's your extra energy. Now, if the side opposite of the side impacted by the bullet were supported and the force of gravity providing a moment, then it would be interesting to see how high the block went.

Next, I guess you would have had to notice that the center of the rotation was NOT at the center of the block. The center of the block, or the spot where the nail was (the resting pivot point) was actually creating a circle on it's way up, (like a wobble), which was the point where the initial moment is just maintained in a conservation of forces.

To explain a little more about this conservation, consider that as the weight of the lead travels in one direction towards the earth that it is affected by gravity, adding to the spin, and as it rotates around in opposition of gravitational forces tends to slow the spin.

I gathered most of this when I noticed the wobble as the block rose into the air.

And when the block was hit direct center, the potential energy from gravity was never converted. And in fact, if the bullet had hit at he very end of the wood then almost exactly half the weight of the block, and it's potential energy from gravity was converted just into the spinning forces. I am sure there is a way to calculate the potential energy stored in one half the weight of the block (considering a variable torque effect?) and how much energy it would take to cause the rotation.

I get it. The energy balances itself. When the block doesnt spin, the energy is already balanced. But when it spins, spinning balances the energy. Think about it. 100%energy of bullet = 100%resistance of block to go equal high. 50% of resistance is on the left, and 50% on the right. In the center, 100% of energy lifts 100% of block to the same high. On the side, 100% of energy lifts 50% resistance, which leaves another 50% of energy which is recycled by the other side of the block through rotation. This is like when you became Thor with the spinning wheel that put less resistance when it was spinning.

I have a different way to look at the conservation of momentum: when the bullet hits the block aligned with the center of gravity of the block, all the linear momentum is transferred to the block and no rotation is produced. However, when the bullet hits off-axis, we can decompose the vertical momentum vector in two components: one in the direction of the center of gravity of the block and one perpendicular to the rotation axis. The first one will translate into linear x,y motion of the center of gravity and the other one into angular momentum. The bigger the off-axis distance is, the smaller the contribution to the linear momentum will be.

I propose to repeat the experiment using a rectangular block where the off-axis impact is as big as possible (block length/height ratio 4:1 or more). This should make the height difference between the on-axis and off-axis impacts more evident.

This is one of the things I found extremely counter intuitive about kinematics. The short answer is that while linear momentum is invariant under translations, angular momentum is not. For example, an asteroid traveling extremely fast but directly at the sun will run straight into the sun, and that's it. Now point the asteroid just slightly off center, and it will end up orbiting around the sun with some angular momentum.
So look at the block and bullet situation from the Center of Mass perspective, because that's usually the most convenient to work with. In the first instance, the bullet is traveling directly at the center of mass. In the second instance, the bullet velocity is not directly towards the center of mass. So in the second instance, the system actually starts with some angular momentum with respect to the COM as soon as the bullet is out of the gun.
The hard part is intuition we have that 'everything is exactly the same, except the gun is shifted 2 inches'. Everything is the same with regards to linear momentum, but 2 inches means everything to angular momentum. Energy is still conserved, it's just with regards to the COM the the second system starts with more rotational KE.

Several good answers and I'm a little late to the party but...

Given that the difference in penetration depth is expected to be very small, the obvious first answer is to increase the total travel of the bullets by lowering the density of the medium.  Lots of people are suggesting using styrofoam... which is not feasible, since the total mass of a styrofoam block that could halt a bullet would be enough that the experiment simply wouldn't work.  I've seen ballistic gel mentioned, but it lacks the rigidity to accurately model the original experiment.  I have similar objections to various other types of materials that I can think of.

One solution to these is to use a composite object.  Given that we're most interested in the end of the path through the object, you could create a block made of layers of wood of different densities.  Assuming a total penetration of approximately two inches, create a block that is composed of 1.5 inches of the original material (pine?) on the top and bottom, and replace the middle section with a lighter material like balsa wood.  Perhaps have an intermediate layer of a third type that has a density between the two  The bulk of the energy of penetration would be spent on the harder outside layer, while the "target" layer would allow the last of the penetration energy to be expended over a much longer distance.

The resultant composite block would retain rigidity and could be adjusted to more closely match the mass of the original experimental block.

Actually you could hollow out the block and fill it with ballistic gel for a similar effect.  Might still lose some of the rotational energy to pressure waves in the non-rigid gel however.  Would be an interesting experiment either way :)

I thought about this and came up with a couple of ways to improve the experiment. If you keep the moment of inertia as small as possible while increasing the mass of the block this will give you the largest difference in bullet penetration. The easiest way to do this would be to use a lead cylinder instead of a nail in the center of the block or glue lead disks to the outside of the block. 

Another way would be to increase the bullet's kinetic energy and/or use a weaker material. This would allow the bullet to travel farther into the block which would amplify the small difference between the two. You would need to run tests to make sure the bullet wouldn't penetrate all the way through. 

One last thing to consider is if you glue to the outside of the block instead of nailing into it you will be able to penetrate past the center of the block. This will also reduce internal stresses that could skew your results.

If you want a bigger difference in discernible bullet penetration, you need to create a larger moment-arm for the off-center case. There is an upper-limit to this, though, because wood can only handle a certain amount of internal stresses before being catastrophically damaged.

For those who think energy is being generated ex nihilo in this experiment, consider the work required to bring the bullet to rest within the block's reference frame, which is different between the two cases. The key difference is that more work is required to slow the bullet in the first case (when the bullet hits the block head-on) than in the second case. And, assuming similar internal shear forces within the block, the bullet will be lodged deeper when it hits head on versus when it hits near one of the sides. This difference in work/internal heat generation arises from the fact that when the bullet hits head on, the block is prohibited from rotating because no net moment is generated, meaning that the bullet must be slowed to the actual linear velocity of the center of mass of the block. However, when the bullet hits off-center, the bullet only needs to be slowed to the linear velocity of the block PLUS the Omega-R velocity of its distance from the block's center of gravity. This means that the kinetic energy that the bullet loses is actually different in the two cases (it loses less energy in the rotating case).  The two systems (rotating and non-rotating) actually end up with two different final energy levels, even though they began with the same energy level and have identical linear kinetic energies. The bullet travels deeper into the non-rotating block, and so more of the initial kinetic energy is dissipated into heat. Less energy dissipation occurs in the rotating block, which is why the presence of its nonzero rotational kinetic energy does not violate conservation laws. Cool problem!!!

Outside of conservation of momentum, the explanation for ALL stationary and spinning blocks rising at different heights has a few things unmentioned and left for consideration .  Everyone is assuming that all of the rounds of ammunition used in the experiment are loaded precisely identical to one another.  In reality, such is never the case due to sheer cost to the manufacturer.  They're loaded only close enough to make a combat-accurate shot every time.

The powder charges in the rounds of ammunition are loaded by weight, not by grains of powder (assuming the powder is all the same smokeless variety from the same manufacturing lot).  In order to have multiple rounds exactly (or as close as possible) the same as one another, they would have to have their casings closely inspected for perfection in their walls, their bullets closely inspected during the manufacturing process for lead/copper content and diameter (assuming the bullets are jacketed), and the powder charges loaded by number of grains rather than simply dropping in the same weight.

Getting the primers to match exactly is a whole other bag of cats to deal with.

Then there's the firearm used...   Were the chamber and barrel perfectly clean for each shot?  Was a dry barrel lubricant used?

Then there's the environment....   It'd be interesting to see this done in a lab with the firearm mounted in a perfectly vertical, perfectly stationary apparatus on a hard floor as opposed to someone's grassy back yard.

To show that the linear velocity of the (block + bullet) is independent of where the bullet strikes: Vcm = P / M , where Vcm is the velocity of the centre of mass, P linear momentum, M total mass. Apply this to the bullet + block system (i.e. M= m /bullet + m /block etc.). The dashes can mean either divide or like m /bullet means mass of bullet. P is conserved since no external forces, and since P (before) = m /bullet * v /bullet, then Vcm = P (before) / M , or rather Vcm = (m /bullet * v /bullet) divided by (m /bullet + m /block).

To wit:

1. what is the average/SD of the amount of gun powder in each cartridge? (i.e. how to show that you are getting the same amount of oomph in each case?) Ditto mass of the bullet.

2. How can you be sure the same amount of energy is required to get a bullet to the same depth along a piece of wood? Wood is not uniform. Maybe by many (many many) repetitions one can get some empirical evidence to statistically account for any differences.

3. Did you show that the pieces of wood had, in fact, the same mass? Uh, no.

3.5 Nor did you properly set up the experiment to enable valid observation (yeah.... the one on the right was 3 pine needles higher!) of what may well be a very small but valid height difference.

I calculated the answer for this problem. Here is the answer:
h=1/(2*g)*v^2/(m1^2*(1/m1+1/m2+L^2/I))^2, where v is the velocity of the bullet. m1,m2 is the mass of the block and bullet respectively. L is the distance between the bullet and the center of the block. I is the rotary inertia of the block. Clearly, h decreases with L. You are wrong.

Your statement about conservation of energy is correct. But your statement about conservation of momentum is wrong.

Momentum is conserved in an ELASTIC COLLISION.

There are no truly elastic collisions. But some come close. It must be that this bullet/block collision is very INELASTIC, and differently so in the two cases (center strike vs. offset strike).

Any material will be plastically deformed by the bullet, even at a microscopic level, when hit by the bullet. If the block was made of a denser material, the difference in indentation/penetration would just be even harder to observe. A perfectly elastic collision, where kinetic energy is completely conserved, is impossible in practice.

Hi Derek! Awesome riddle!

The physics suggest that if you want to exaggerate the difference in bullet depth, you should exaggerate the off-center distance of the bullet's entry point.

Case in point: KE_before = KE_lin + KE_rot + U
Where U is internal energy. We'll take U to be representative of bullet depth.

Since both cases have the same KE_before and KE_lin, we know that KE_rot must be equal to the discrepancy in U. This can be amplified simply by elongating r in (1/2)Iw^2 (where w = vr).
Why do you say that the bullet gets "forward pointing momentum" while the block gets "upward pointing momentum"? They both go in the same direction, no?

We know this: momentum is conserved and kinetic energy is not conserved. Try this experiment. Prepare 4 different blocks. First block with homogenous density for example iron, second block with homogenous but less dense material (wood …), third block where density is concentrated around centre of gravity (wood block with iron in the middle) and finally forth block where density is concentrated at the edges of block (iron block with wood in the middle).  And heights will not be the same.

On understanding the angular momentum: keep in mind that the system you're concerned about is the wood block + bullet system. In one case the bullet is fired toward the center of mass of the wood block and thus there is no angular momentum in that system. In the other case the bullet is fired off center and thus there is angular momentum. Think of two cars in a head on collision, either directly aligned or off center, if they hit off center when they hit they'll rotate.

This got me too. However, according to the Wikipedia article on angular momentum, something doesn't have to spin to have one - it can move in a straight line, but *relative to a point NOT on that line*, it DOES have angular momentum. Now, considering that in the 2nd case neither the bullet before nor the block after(?) is moving along a line that includes their common center of mass, clearly there is more to the whole angular momentum than just the spinning of the block... :)

Wrong. The blocks rise to the same height because momentum is conserved. Total energy is also conserved, but mechanical energy alone isn't: the rotational energy in the spinning block is equivalent to more heat and damage in the non-spinning block. The only reason that both blocks don't reach exactly the same heights in the experiments is due to a difference in conditions, in particular the consistency of the gun shots. These differences are irrelevant to the underlying physics.

Hitting a 5-lb block dead-center with 4 pounds of force causes the wood to absorb and dissipate all 4 pounds of energy through deformation.  But because of leverage, only one pound is necessary to lift the end of the block just a little.  That means 1 pound will be lost moving the block, leaving only 3 pounds to penetrate the wood, which should leave you with measurably less penetration.

if you were to use a material that is less dense than wood, the bullets should travel further into each block. The two distances should hopefully scale proportionally and become more easily measured the softer you go.

Use a much longer block, and you should be able to create a measurable difference in penetration depth.  If your block weighs 5 lbs, and you hit it dead center with 5.1 lbs of force, it should just barely nudge the block.  Hitting it with 4.9 lbs of force would, of course, not be enough.  But, if the block is a foot long, and you hit it way over on the edge with less than 5 lbs, you know because of leverage it will lift the end of the block a little. One thing that's not explained in the video is why a non-spinning bullet hitting can hit non-spinning block, make that block spin and still conserve angular momentum. The answer is that, since the off-centre bullet is not travelling along a line through the centre of mass of the bullet-block system, its motion has a rotational component with respect to that centre of mass. Therefore, there is non-zero angular momentum before the collision.

You can actually choose any point in space, it just usually is easier to calculate with the centre of mass or an obvious axis of rotation as your point of origin.

The trick in angular momentum is that you need a fixed origin first. It doesn't matter, which point you choose as your origin, a.m. will equally be conserved but you mustn't change your origin midway through the experiment.

Let's choose the centre of the block: the bullet, although it flies straight,  its angular momentum is non-zero, as it doesn't head straight towards the centre. Once the bullet is stopped by the block, that angular momentum is conserved by the spinning block-bullet complex.

Allan Medeiros you are wrong. Angular momentum L = r x P, where the vector r starts from the center of the block and heading to the bullet. P is the linear momentum of the bullet, |L| = |r x P| = m.|r|.sin(r,v).v = m.v.a, where a is the distance between the middle of the block and the bullet whole, also L = I*w , where I is the ineria and w is the angular velogicy so you get 
w =  a*m*v/I, 
Kinetic rotational en E = I*w^2/2 = a^2m^2*v^2 /(2.I) = (m*a^2/I)*E0 where E0 = m*v^2/2 - init kin energy

We want to maximize the kinetic energy transferred into angular momentum, so we should maximize the torque applied T=Fxd=(m•a)xd. m is fixed, so we can affect the torque by modifying either -a, the deceleration of the bullet or d, the distance the bullet is off-centre. Notably, mass of the block shouldn't affect the torque applied. Thus, a wider block (allowing the bullet to be shot more off-centre) and a harder block should allow more of the kinetic energy to be converted into angular momentum.

The off-centred bullet has an angular momentum before it hits the block: its angular momentum is the cross product of its position vector (relative to the centre of mass) and its linear momentum vector. The centre of mass of the entire system almost coincides with the centre of the block, so the position and momentum vectors of the bullet aren't parallel, thus the bullet has an angular momentum.

Correct answer:The center happens to be the 'center of mass' of the block as it has uniform density,so if the center of gravity applying on that spot is 'X' then the gravity applying on the second spot is lesser(X-X/2).So the bullet's kinetic energy(Y) should be more than X to make a lift.So (Y-X) energy is utilized in lifting the block from the center, and (Y- X/2) is utilized to lift it from the side,(X-X/2) converts as rotation.All in all only Y energy is applied,so it goes to same height

I disagree. Linear momentum and angular momentum are conserved independently. It is true that the bullet provide angular momentum to the block, but this does not come at the expense of linear momentum.
If you choose your reference point on the vertical line through the center of the block, the initial (after the bullet is fired & before it hit the block) angular momentum of the whole system (bullet + block) is already different for the two setups.

I don't think a difference in deformation is the correct explanation.

The reason the second block has angular momentum after the impact is because the second system had angular momentum before the impact.  The angular momentum of the system pre-impact is the cross product of the bullet's momentum and the vector from the bullet to the system center of mass,  r X mv, since the block has zero momentum and the bullet has zero angular momentum.

In the first system, r X mv for the bullet is zero.

To demonstrate the difference, you want to reduce the amount of energy lost.

Energy is more strongly dependent on velocity than mass (velocity is squared, mass is not), so to have a greater final KE, you want to make the block less massive, since by conservation of momentum v is inversely proportional to mass.

So try reducing the size of the block to an absolute minimum. It would be really cool to actually see this difference demonstrated in a future video!

I feel the experiment was prone to tricking people. The problem is that most people think about the collisions as being inelastic, not realizing that a lot of the KE of the bullet was spent on stuff other than moving the block (that's where the extra energy came from that so confused Henry and Destin). Plus you didn't provide any quantifiable data to allow viewers to check it. When I did an estimation of inelastic KE transfer I found that the block should have shot up at ~40m/s (40gr @ 330m/s).

Since you are looking for a very small phenomena, I would suggest using a much more controlled set of circumstances. Change out the wood block for something that is configured of thousands of discreet layers (plastic bag comes to mind within a built structure). This would give you very consistent material. Polystyrene blocks and airsoft or metal bb guns might have better penetrations, but then air resistance will play a bigger role, right?  

Also note that no 2 blocks of wood will ever be identical.  Wood is organic so there will always be some slight variation, even in the same original board it could vary from inch to inch in density, moisture content and hardness.

I do.. assuming we use the same units for measurement (say mm), 1% of  10mm's is not very easy to spot, while 1% of 100cm's is a bit better using the same "ruler". 1% of 10mm would be 1/10th of a mm, whileas 1% of 100cm would be 10mm, which, if measured using the same "ruler" or measure instrument, would give you an actual reading.

This does of course, mean that we'd have to resize them as well, to allow for further travel without the bullet leaving the material of choice.

Conservation of energy is perhaps the single most reliable law of science. However, energy -- though it is never created or destroyed -- can and does continuously change forms. A bouncing ball converts energy between kinetic and potential forms, and during each bounce some energy becomes heat & sound, so the next rebound is less high.

Here, in one case more energy went into deforming the wood, and in the other case more energy went into making the block spin, but both conserved total energy.

This problem is tricky because you have to know all these rules and know that they apply.  You have to know that conservation of energy (which we've heard is an unchanging fact) is not reliable in this case.  You have to know about conservation of momentum, which doesn't come up in everyday conversation.  You have to know about the difference between linear and angular momentum.  You have to know that kinetic energy is not conserved in this case, which isn't obvious at all at first. (it is now)

I don't think you are using the correct terminology. The rotation of an object is caused by torque. If the bullet is shot in the middle, there will be no net torque, while if the bullet is shot off the center of mass there will be a net torque, causing rotation in the block. That is all true, but the fact of the matter is angular momentum is conserved separately of linear momentum, so it does not matter if there is a net torque on the block or not.

Ah Ha! If the bullet + block is considered "the system" then it has angular momentum from the start. The c.m. OF THE SYSTEM is somewhere between the block c.m. and the bullet c.m. Thus, the system has some angular momentum due to the bullet's velocity vector not intersecting that c.m. The angular momentum of the block+bullet after the hit has to be the same as the angular momentum of the block+bullet before the hit.

the rotation is caused by the moment of inertia - when the bullet is shot in the middle the inertia on both sides is equal.
when the bullet is shot off center the inertia on both sides where the bullet hits is unequal causing a moment of inertia.

Yay, my answer was correct!

=> Total Energy = Gravitational Potential Energy + Rotational Energy.
=> Rotational Energy = Torque * angle moved in radians.
=> Torque = Force * distance_center_block_to_place_where_Bullet_Shot * sine(angle_between_center_block_Place_Where_bullet_Shot)
=> angle = 180 for bullet hitting at the center. sine(180) = 0, Tarque = 0. hence TOTAL ENERGY = GRAVITATIONAL POTENTIAL ENERGY
=> angle != 0 or != 180 for bullet hitting side, hence Tarque != 0. hence ENERGY = GPE + ROTATIONAL ENERGY

The mental hurdle with angular momentum is being able to understand that even if a particle is moving in a straight line, it still has angular momentum from any arbitrary axis (in this case the cg of the block).  This can be shown mathematically because l=rXf  Or, for the magnitude of l, l=rp sin(theta). The angular momentum you can see after impact can traced back to the moment of impact, where the angular momentum = the linear momentum of the bullet times the horizontal distance from the cg.

Rotational momentum doesn't always involve things "rotating" by definition. Might not make much sense at first, but if you imagine a bullet moving off to the right of some block (not even touching), the relative rotational momentum has to do with the rate of change of the angle between the line of the bullet's path and the line connecting the two objects. Hence when it gets lodged into the block, the rate changes (becomes zero) so something else needs to gain the rotational momentum.

The momentum is conserved when transferring momentum to another object. In this case, there was no rotational momentum to begin with. Just like an object at rest in linear systems. However, when a FORCE is applied, energy is placed into the system and both energy and momentum are conserved. In rotational, a torque is applied and thus the block will rotate. This required a transfer of energy. Energy can be used to transmit linear momentum into rotational momentum, since both only require motion.

The loss of the bullet's kinetic energy is due to the work done by the resistant force (or frictional force) exerted by the wood on the bullet as the bullet is travelling within the wood:
loss of K.E. of the bullet = (resistant force)x(penetration distance).

What you can change is the resistant force by using a block of less solid material instead. To make sure that the bullet would not completely penetrate through the block, it may be necessary to make the block much thicker.

What he is talking about in the end is the energy of the bullet. 97% of the kinetic energy (of the bullet) is lost due to deformation, heat and sound. So only 3% of the initial kinetic energy moves the block. Since the ratio of potential (or gravitational) energy to rotational energy is 2:1, this results in 2% of the energy being transformed into potential energy and only 1% into rotational energy.

Horizontal test into ballistic (clear) gelatin mounted on a platform with a central axis (vertical) on a sled. Larger caliber PISTOL cartridge to increase surface area while not significantly increasing velocity. 1st shot central to axis, second shot to extreme edge away from axis. Measure both depth of bullet in ballistic gel and rotational movement (on axis) and total movement (on sled). To get better accuracy hand load ammunition and chronograph each test shot.

To make the difference in depth measurable just use a material that is easier penetrable but not too much lighter. This way the ratio between energy 'invested' into spinning and difference in depth is increased.

Use a less dense material so the bullet will travel further into it, Polystyrene for example. Use a much bigger block so that the bullet doesn't travel all the way through it. As the bullets will travel further that 1% difference will be easier to see and measure.
